title.rendered: The Good, Bad and Ugly of Living With Your Sibling

content.rendered:
After years of living under your parents’ roof, you finally have the opportunity to spread your wings and fly. You’re on your own. The scent of freedom is in the air, as you triumphantly pack your meager childhood possessions and prepare to move out. You venture forth into the great unknown. You find a fabulous new place and a roommate to share it with. But then someone has a bright idea. Maybe it was your well-meaning mother. Or perhaps a friend who doesn’t know any better. But someone suggests moving in with your sibling. And they’re all about it. After all, you both need to split costs. And sharing household responsibilities is something you already know how to do together. It’ll be fun, right? Well, there’s no turning back now. So before you resign yourself to sulking, here’s the bright side of living with your sibling.

Navigating living with your sibling

Hypothetical situations aside, Caitlin Ledger lives with her brother in Philadelphia. And she says living with a sibling was a joint decision that’s yielded many benefits. Ledger and her brother enjoy the comfort of familiarity. Plus all the financial and social benefits of having a roommate, which allows them to experience a new city together.

That being said, it is a rough adjustment to be living with your sibling. After being apart for years, they found living together wasn’t as easy as it had once been, having developed their own habits and ways of living over the years.

“We found ourselves bickering over how to do dishes, how the fridge should be organized, leaving the TV or lights on, and so on.” says Ledger. So that’s something to keep in mind when living with your roommate. “My brother and two of my other roommates are night owls. Dan is a bartender and I work a 9-5. He likes to play his guitar and video games after he gets off work late. So there have been a few nights where I’ve zombied down the hall in the middle of the night and had to close his door, or tell him to turn it down.”

The ugly is easier to handle when living with your sibling

There was also an altercation involving all the roommates. Who may have ganged-up on said brother about toilet seat etiquette and, of course, there’s always the thing that’s almost impossible not to fight about among roommates:

“Oh my god, talking money with someone in your family sucks enough. But having to pay bills with him makes my head want to explode sometimes,” Ledger says. “What’s different about living with your sibling is that we can easily call each other out on being irrational. And we have no filter with what comes out of our mouths. We’ve had to have some conversations about this, realizing that we can’t approach roommate situations with a sibling attitude. I can’t pout and stomp my feet to get my way and he can’t scold me like his little sister. It has to be two adults when living with your sibling, solving a problem logically and fairly.”

You’ll make the best roommates

After a few weeks of moving in with your sibling and getting to know each other in your new roles as adult roommates, like Ledger and her brother, you’d realize how great living with your sibling actually is. Previous co-living experience really pays off when it comes to navigating the day-to-day.

“There are lots of benefits to living with a sibling since you already know their habits. Dan loves to take long showers so I make sure that I get in the shower before him so I’m not waiting for half an hour,” says Ledger. We also both love to snack. So I’ve been hiding some snacks I don’t want to share in my room (which he’ll find out about after he reads this, so I’ll have to change my hiding spot)! And lastly, I can also tell when he’s in a bad mood, so I know when to stay away or ask him what’s wrong. In that sense, living with your roommate can be very comforting too!”

You’ll get all the support you need

Armed with the knowledge of a sibling’s strengths and weaknesses, and the ability to speak candidly, moving in with your sibling can help you enjoy a closer relationship than others.

“I consider my brother one of my very best friends,” Ledger adds. “We bicker sometimes, but every time there’s an issue, we get better and better at solving it — which I think will really help our relationship in the long run and yours too, if you plan on living with your sibling. We are already so close, but now I feel like we are becoming more friends than close siblings.”

And even if they drink all the O.J. or bump Call of Duty at 2 a.m., you won’t regret moving in with your sibling. Your sibling was your first roommate, after all.

D’you know what else Roomi does outside of helping its readers decide on whether or not to move in with their sibling? With our ever-increasing lists of rooms and roommates across the world, we help you find your perfect match! Download the app here and hop on the easiest ride home, ever!

jetpack-related-posts.author: Team Roomi
jetpack-related-posts.excerpt: When moving out of your parent's house, you can consider a plethora of potential roommates. You can live with a friend, your SO, a complete stranger, or your sibling. Believe us when we say that every available option has its own set of pros and cons. So if you're thinking…

jetpack-related-posts.author: Team Roomi
jetpack-related-posts.excerpt: In today's world where co-parenting is no longer restricted to the conventional "mom and dad" arrangement, we can all learn a thing or two from setups that veer away from the norm. jetpack-related-posts.author: Team Roomi
jetpack-related-posts.excerpt: Co living is tough on its own, but if you decide to co live with someone of the opposite sex, it can be tougher. Even if you've co lived with a sibling of the opposite sex when you were home, it's not quite the same when you share an apartment…

jetpack-related-posts.title: How to Live with a Stressful Roommate
jetpack-related-posts.author: Team Roomi
jetpack-related-posts.excerpt: No matter how hard you try and avoid it, it's almost inevitable that at some point you'll end up living with stressful people.
